abstract.para: This book covers the use of the Akeeba CMS Update suite of tools for updating the Joomla! CMS.

section.title: What is Akeeba CMS Update?
section.para: Akeeba CMS Update is the better update component for the Joomla! CMS. Its one mission is to check for Joomla! updates and let you install them in an efficient way, even on the usually problematic shared hosting. Unlike the Joomla! Update component distributed with Joomla!, Akeeba CMS Update has some unique features:

listitem.para: Improved update determination. While Joomla! Update uses the outdated JUpdate library, our component uses a new library built from scratch, based on our 7+ years of experience in providing live update features in our software. The end result is a more robust implementation which is far less likely to "get stuck".

Retroactive bug fixes. One of the major problems with Joomla! Update being part of the CMS itself is that any bugs discovered in its code will only be fixed in a future version of Joomla!. But how do you update to this new version of Joomla! when the updater itself won't let you? Akeeba CMS Update allows you to update it before updating Joomla!, swiftly overcoming this chicken and egg problem.
Backup on update. If you have Akeeba Backup installed you can automatically backup your site before a new Joomla! version is installed. Even better, you can choose which backup profile to use.

Update notification by email. If you have several sites it's extremely hard to know which ones need to be updated and time consuming to do so – at least without paying a premium for a third party, closed source, site monitoring service. Akeeba CMS Update will have your site email when there is an update available. The link in the email allows for a two-click update: one click on the link, another one to verify your intention. No login required. It even integrates with Admin Tools to provide an smooth auto-login experience. The frequency of the emails is configurable.

Integrated notification of all Joomla! releases, including the testing (dev) branch. By default, Joomla! Update only displays available updates in the current CMS version branch. Akeeba CMS Update by default shows you all available update options, allowing you to choose which version to install. This is of course configurable.

Alternate connectivity to update server. Whereas most Joomla! versions require you to have the fopen() URL wrappers enabled, Akeeba CMS Update will intelligently choose between that or cURL to fetch updates. It all happens automatically. All you know is that it just works!

Hybrid restoration engine. The biggest nightmare of CMS users on shared hosting is a situation aptly described as "permissions hell": different files and folders owned by different system users with wildly different permissions. This makes it impossible to update a site either with PHP direct file writes or by uploading files via FTP. When everyone else fails, our vast experience in backup restoration technology allows us to succeed with the Hybrid engine which intelligently uses direct file writes or FTP, on a file-by-file (and directory-by-directory) basis.

Segmented download for improved stability. Certain Joomla! updates are unwieldy in size for a large percentage of cheap hosting. The usual outcome is that the update download fails with a timeout error and you, the CMS user, are left with no option to install the update. Our advanced downloader technology allows us to download the update files one small chunk at a time, overcoming hosting limits. This is transparent to you and all you know is that it just works, every single time.

Automatic updates. Forget about having to log in to your site to perform the update to the next Joomla! version. Using our provided CLI script you can easily create a CRON job which automatically updates Joomla! to the latest version when it's available. On top of that, it will automatically backup your site before update. Even better, you don't have to pay a penny to use it – unlike third party, closed source, site monitoring services.

section.para: Akeeba CMS Update is provided free of charge under the GNU General Public License version 3 or, at your option, any later version published by the Free Software Foundation. It's truly Free software, in every sense of the word.
section.bridgehead: Why did we build this component instead of contribute it to Joomla!?
section.para: Akeeba Ltd and its developers have been involved with Joomla! since its first day. We have been publishing our acclaimed Akeeba Backup software (and its predecessor, JoomlaPack) since 2006, helping millions of sites to have up-to-date backups and move between servers effectively. Since 2010 we have also been publishing Admin Tools, a collection of security and utilitarian features for the Joomla! CMS. One of Admin Tools' features, Joomla! update, has been included in Joomla! itself since version 2.5. It's rebranded as "Joomla! Update".

In the roughly one year and a half between the release of Joomla! 2.5 and starting work on Akeeba CMS Update we identified several issues with Joomla! Update. Sadly, many of them required either the Joomla! project to change its distribution policy (i.e. providing updates for Joomla! Update before a new Joomla! release is issued) or stepped into the territory of the Joomla! libraries themselves. The scope of the necessary changes was impossible to muster within a project that follows a "design by committee" approach for all code decisions. Moreover, some of the most advanced features (like backup on update) could never make it into Joomla! itself. This is understandable, the Joomla! project usually doesn't promote specific companies' products, as would happen with Akeeba Backup in this case.

Instead of wasting precious months to get few small changes in the core, without even getting to an end result we'd feel comfortable with, we decided to build our own vastly improved updater and put it out there for real people to use it in the real world and prove its worth. Maybe, in the future, some of its advanced features will be retrofitted to Joomla! Update and the core Joomla! libraries. We intend to keep this product around and update it often, based on our clients' feedback.

section.title: Server environment requirements
section.para: In order to work, Akeeba CMS Update requires the following server software environment:

listitem.para: Joomla! and PHP version compatibilities are detailed in our Version Compatibility matrix.
Any database server compatible with Joomla!.
Minimum 24Mb of PHP memory_limit. More is better. Akeeba CMS Update may run on servers with lesser memory limits, but some features may not work optimally or at all.
The cURL PHP module or fopen() URL wrappers must be installed and enabled.

section.para: As far as the browser is concerned, you can use any modern browser supported by the Joomla! CMS, including most mobile devices' browsers.
In any case, you must make sure that Javascript is enabled on your browser for the component to work at all.

section.title: Normal installation
section.para: Installing Akeeba CMS Update is no different than installing any other Joomla! extension on your site. You can read the complete instructions for installing Joomla! extensions on the official help page. Throughout this chapter we assume that you are familiar with these instructions and we will not duplicate them.

You can download the latest installation packages by visiting our site at https://www.akeebabackup.com. Use the Download link on the top toolbar to open the page of the official releases and locate the Akeeba CMS Update package. Clicking on "View Releases" will get you to a list of all releases up-to-date. Click on the "View files" of the latest release to view a file list. Find the item you want to download and click on "Download file". In any case, do not extract the ZIP files yet!

Log in to your site's administrator section. Click on the Extensions, Install/Uninstall (Joomla! 1.5) link on the top menu. In this page, locate the Browse button in the Upload Package File area. Locate the installation ZIP file you had previously downloaded and select it. Back to the page, click on the Upload File & Install button. After a short while, Joomla! will tell you that the component and its associated extensions have been installed.

If you can't install Akeeba CMS Update and you are receiving messages regarding unwritable directories, inability to move files or other similar file system related error messages, please do not ask us for support. These errors stem from your site set up and can best be resolved by asking for help in the official Joomla! forums. If, however, you receive a blank page, an Internal Server Error page or a timeout error message, please proceed to the manual installation section of this documentation.

section.title: Manual installation
section.para: Sometimes Joomla! is unable to properly extract ZIP archives due to technical limitations on your server. In this case, you can follow a manual installation procedure.

First, you have to extract the installation ZIP file in a subdirectory named cmsupdate on your local PC. Then, upload the entire subdirectory inside your site's temporary directory. At this point, there should be a subdirectory named cmsupdate inside your site's temporary directory which contains all of the ZIP package's files.

If you are unsure where your site's temporary directory is located, you can look it up by going to the Global Configuration, click on the Server tab and take a look at the Path to Temp-folder setting. The default setting is the tmp directory under your site's root. Rarely, especially on automated installations using Fantastico, this might have been assigned the system-wide /tmp directory. In this case, please consult your host for instructions on how to upload files inside this directory, or about changing your Joomla! temporary directory back to the default location and making it writable.

Assuming that you are past this uploading step, click on the Extensions, Extensions Manager link on the top menu. In this page, locate the Install Directory edit box in the Install from Directory area. It is already filled in with the absolute path to your temporary directory, for example /var/www/joomla/tmp. Please append /cmsupdate to it. As per our example, it should look something like /var/www/joomla/tmp/cmsupdate. Then, click on the Install button.

If you still can't install Akeeba CMS Update and you are receiving messages regarding unwritable directories, inability to move files or other similar file system related error messages, please do not ask us for support. These errors stem from your site set up and can best be resolved by asking for help in the official Joomla! forums.

section.title: Updating to the latest version
section.para: You can easily check for the latest published version of the Akeeba CMS Update component by visiting https://www.akeebabackup.com/download/latest. The page lists the version and release date of the latest Akeeba CMS Update release. If your release is out of date, simply click on the Download link to download the install package of the latest release to your PC.

Updating Akeeba CMS Update to the latest version is by no means different than installing the component. You do not have to uninstall the previous version; in fact, you are discouraged from doing so. Simply follow the installation instructions so as to install the latest Akeeba CMS Update version over the existing Akeeba CMS Update installation. That's all! All your settings are preserved.

You can easily update Akeeba CMS Update through the built-in Joomla! extensions update feature, included in all currently supported versions of Joomla!. Just go to Extensions, Extensions Manager menu item at the top of your administrator back-end and click on Update. You may want to click on Find Updates to make sure that you are viewing the latest available update information.

section.title: The main page
section.para: The main page of the component offers you an overview of your update status. If your site is up to date it looks like this:
From top to bottom you have the following areas:

listitem.para: The top part consisting of the update notification pane, the Update Options pane and the buttons to reinstall Joomla!, install the update or reload update information.
The bottom area with a list of all available Joomla! versions.

section.para: Let's see what each area is supposed to do.
section.bridgehead: The top area - Main update status and actions
section.para: The top half of the page is dedicated to presenting the backup status and allowing you to perform updates.

The first thing you see is the backup status pane. It's green when your site is up to date, red when an update is available. It informs you of the currently installed Joomla! version and the available updated version (if one is available).
Right below it you can find the Update Options pane. In here you can define the following setting which are taken into account when updating your site:

listitem.para: Backup on update. Shown only when Akeeba Backup is installed. If set to Yes, a backup of your site will be taken right before installing the new Joomla! version on it. The backup profile used can be set up in the options page.

FTP User and FTP Password. On many hosts (notable: most shared hosting providers) trying to extract the backup directly will fail due to file ownership and permissions. In this case you just need to enable Joomla!'s FTP system through your site's Global Configuration page. Out of security reasons many users prefer not to enter their FTP username and password in that page. However these are required when performing the update. This is why you get the chance to enter them in Akeeba CMS Update before performing the update.

important.para: These options appear only when necessary. If no options are necessary on your site you will not see the Update Options pane at all.

section.para: You can hide this pane by clicking the Update options button below it.
Right below you can find the update buttons, which can be one or more of the following:

listitem.para: Reinstall Joomla! x.y.z. If your installed Joomla! release is still available for download you will be given the option to reinstall it. This is useful when you suspect that some Joomla! files are corrupt, missing or tampered with.
Update to Joomla! x.y.z. If an update is available you are given the option to update to it; this is what this component is all about. By clicking on this button you will be begin the update process.

section.para: Finally, you can see the Reload update information button and the last update check time. You only need to click on the Reload update information button if you believe that the displayed update information is stuck / out of date. This is why you are presented with the last update check time. It tells you exactly when Akeeba CMS Update last checked for available Joomla! updates.

important.para: Let's make this clear. You DO NOT normally need to use the Reload update information button. Akeeba CMS Update will check for updates automatically. The frequency of these checks is defined in the Options page. You only need to press this button if a new Joomla! version is out and you don't want to wait until the next scheduled update check.

Akeeba CMS Update does not use the same update mechanism as Joomla! Update. One component might show an available update while the other doesn't. This doesn't mean that either component is broken. It only means that each component checked for updates at a different time, therefore seeing a different Joomla! update status, hence the disparity in the displayed results. Please do not file a bug report about this, it's not a bug, it's the very definition of how software updates work in every software, from Windows to Ubuntu Linux and from Joomla! to WordPress.

section.bridgehead: The bottom area - All available Joomla! versions
section.para: By default, Akeeba CMS Update will attempt to retrieve the update information across all available release channels:

listitem.para: STS. These are the Short Term Support releases of Joomla!, which have a predefined lifetime of 6 months. These have all the new and improved features but not all third party software is designed for them. Additionally, newer STS versions with an increased minor version number (the number after the first dot) might have subtle changes to their predecessors, potentially causing issues on update.

LTS. These are the Long Term Support releases of Joomla!, with a minimum lifetime of 18 months. No new features are to be found there, only bug and security fixes. These are the recommended versions for most sites requiring increased stability.

Testing. ATTENTION: THERE BE DRAGONS! These are alpha, beta and release candidates of the upcoming Joomla! version, whatever it is. You are only supposed to install them if you are a developer OR if you want to help with testing Joomla! (please do, we need more testers). You are advised to install these versions on test sites, not your production sites. Stability of these version is, by their very definition, NOT guaranteed. In fact the Joomla! developers bet that there is some instability, that's why they kindly request as many users as possible to test these releases and help improve Joomla!. The Joomla! developers cannot possibly test against all possible configurations. Fact: nobody claims to do that, not even multibillion corporations. For example Microsoft also relies on a similar crowdsourced beta testing for its new Windows releases. So, pretty please, if you have 10 minutes to spare every now and then consider installing these testing releases on a test site on your preferred hosting and report any bugs you find. Otherwise you can expect that these bugs will most likely go unnoticed, even if you think it's a glaring issue.

section.para: You can change which versions appear here and which of these versions is reported as an available update in the Options page.

section.title: The options page
section.para: You can access the options page by clicking the Options button found in the toolbar of the main page. On most sites this will be towards the top right-hand corner of the page.
The Options page looks something like this:
The available options are:

listitem.para: Which update sources to read when looking for available Joomla! releases. Your options are:
All sources. This is the recommended option. All of the following sources will be considered, giving you maximum flexibility in your Joomla! update planning.

LTS. These are the Long Term Support releases of Joomla!, with a minimum lifetime of 18 months. No new features are to be found there, only bug and security fixes. These are the recommended versions for most sites requiring increased stability.

STS. These are the Short Term Support releases of Joomla!, which have a predefined lifetime of 6 months. These have all the new and improved features but not all third party software is designed for them. Additionally, newer STS versions with an increased minor version number (the number after the first dot) might have subtle changes to their predecessors, potentially causing issues on update.

Testing. These are alpha, beta and release candidates of the upcoming Joomla! version, whatever it is. These versions are only recommended if you are interested in helping the Joomla! project with testing the CMS.

Custom source. Only the Custom source below will be consulted. This is for advanced users only, unless you are specifically told in the support forum or in Joomla! release notes to use a custom update source.

Only used when the update source is set to All Sources or Custom Source. Enter the full URL to a Joomla! update XML file. If you have no idea what this is you don't need to fill it in; just leave it blank.
The minimum Joomla! stability level which results in an update notification being issued. Your options are:
Any version. Any version, be it STS, LTS or testing.
Newer STS, LTS or current branch releases. Any version except testing releases.
Newer LTS or current branch releases. Any version that is either in the current version branch or the newest LTS branch.
Newer current branch releases. Only newer versions in the current version branch.

Let's understand what current version branch means. Joomla! versions typically consist of three numbers separated by dots, e.g. 1.2.3. The first two numbers (called major and minor version respectively) define the current branch. So, any version beginning with 1.2 –e.g. 1.2.1, 1.2.2, 1.2.3, 1.2.123– belongs to the "1.2 branch". When Akeeba CMS Update considers the current branch it reads your currently installed version and uses its first two numbers to filter available updates. For example, if you had Joomla! 3.1.5 installed it will only show you an available update for Joomla! 3.1.6, but not an available update for Joomla! 3.2.0 or later.
Using the current branch is recommended if you are running an STS release and you have not yet tested if you can safely upgrade your site to the next STS or LTS version of Joomla!.

How often will Akeeba CMS Update check the Joomla! update servers for available updates. The default is 6 hours. Trying to access Akeeba CMS Update more often than that will NOT refresh the updates cache unless you use the Reload update information button.

Akeeba CMS Update comes with an optional plugin which send out emails notifying Super Users for available updates. It will repeat those emails until the updated Joomla! version is installed on your site. This option controls how often those emails will be repeated. By default it's 168 hours (at most once every week). If you want to be reminded at most every day enter 24 (24 hours is one day).

important.para: This and the following option require the update notification email plugin to be enabled in order to have any effect.

listitem.para: Akeeba CMS Update comes with an optional plugin which send out emails notifying Super Users for available updates. If you leave this option blank all Super Users with Receive System emails set to Yes will be notified, which may not be desirable (e.g. you may not want your client to receive these emails). In this case, please enter a comma separated list of email addresses to be notified. The emails you enter MUST belong to existing Super Users on your site with Receive System emails set to Yes.

important.para: This and the previous option require the update notification email plugin to be enabled in order to have any effect.

listitem.para: When this option is enabled, Akeeba CMS Update will take a backup of your site using Akeeba Backup before installing the new Joomla! version. In case the update causes problems with an extension on your site you can roll back to this backup and regain access to your site, exactly as it was immediately prior to the update.

important.para: This and the following option require you to have Akeeba Backup installed and set up on your site. You can use either the free of charge Akeeba Backup Core or the for-a-fee Akeeba Backup Professional without a problem.

listitem.para: Used with the previous option. This determines which Akeeba Backup profile will be used for the backup on update feature. This is a good idea if you have multiple backup profiles for different purposes set up on your site.

important.para: This and the previous option require you to have Akeeba Backup installed and set up on your site. You can use either the free of charge Akeeba Backup Core or the for-a-fee Akeeba Backup Professional without a problem.
